bibl.title: Letter from William Gorgas Crawford to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 14, 1917

div1.p: Gorgas discusses the manning of ambulance sections in France.

div1.head: Letter from William Gorgas Crawford to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 14, 1917
div1.opener:
Gen Gorgas
WCG-fjm
WAR DEPARTMENT
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL
WASHINGTON
Sept. 14, 1917.
Recd Nov. 5
Colonel Jefferson R. Kean, M. C.,
U. S. Expeditionary Forces,
France.
My dear Kean:
div1.p: Yours of August 25th has just been received.

Our present authority for Ambulance Sections is 129.
Forty are to cover American sections on duty in France, and
129 sections to be furnished from the United States. Nine
additional sections have recently been authorized by the Sec-
retary of War.

We have just gotten a cablegram from General Pershing,
asking us not to send more than 20 sections for use with the
French Army; that they did not need any more. We have about
50 under orders for France, but to comply with this cablegram
from General Pershing, we have asked that all but 8 of this
50 be held for further orders. His cablegram also states
that he needs unattached men to fill out the sections he is
taking over in France. We will send them over from Allentown
as soon as we hear how many are wanted. The Chief of Staff
has cabled for information on this subject.

The Marshall is entirely mistaken as to what the French
Mission asked for. I was present at several of the conferences
between the Secretary and the Mission, and it was finally settled
that they would like to have 160 sections, their idea being that
these sections would take entire charge of the transportation of
the wounded for the whole French Army, and in that way, utilize
their own men elsewhere. General Vinal, Military Attache here,
is taking up through the Embassy the matter of the misunderstanding
and I imagine it will soon be corrected.

If General Pershing asks it, I have no doubt the Secretary
will authorize as many sections as you need to take over the
American contingent in France. Everything is ready here for
shipping this whole contingent now, and all that you have to do
is indicate the number wanted, up to the total of 169 sections,
and we can furnish you just as many unassigned men as you wish.

Whenever you want anything, get General Pershing to add it
to one of his cables, and I will do my best to get it for you.
For instance, if you want authority for taking over 43 sections
in France, get General Pershing to ask it. The Chief of Staff
does not like to authorize anything unless he knows it is done
with General Pershing's approval.
